Quick applications lesson

$\det\left(\matrixstart v_1 & v_2 \matrixend\right) = $ Area of parellelogram from $v_1,v_2$
Extends to volume, &c.

Eigenvalues and -vectors

Mapping $T(x) = Ax = \matrixstart 1 & 1 \\ 2 & 0 \matrixend \matrixstart x \\ y \matrixend = \matrixstart x + y \\ 2x \matrixend$

We looked at scaling and changing things to identify special points/vectors (geometric intuition)

Now the algebra

We would like $Av \parallel v \iff Av = \lambda v, \lambda \in \mathbb{R}$
So $Av - \lambda v  = 0$ or $(A - \lambda I)v = 0$

This is only solvable when $\det(A - \lambda I) = 0$ (when $A - \lambda I$ is not invertible)
Solve for $\lambda$ and use that to find one such $v$ that fits.

If $A - \lambda I$ is not invertible, $\ker(A - \lambda I) \neq \{ 0 \}$

Shortcut for $\mathbb{R}^{2 \times 2}$ (assume $A$ is $a,b,c,d$ in the natural order)
$\det(A - \lambda I) = p(\lambda) = \lambda^2 - tr(A)\lambda + \det(A)$
$tr(A) = a + c = $ sum of diagonal
